attachments.fallback: Narrato Blog: 8 Smart Ways to Repurpose Your Blog Content
attachments.text: Ask content marketers what they’re up to and they’re likely to be thinking about the next piece of content they plan to create. As content marketers, we’re all so busy running behind producing a “new” piece that we fail to realize that we might already be sitting on a goldmine of content.  This i
attachments.title: 8 Smart Ways to Repurpose Your Blog Content

attachments.fallback: Narrato Blog: How to Update and Optimize Your Old Blog Posts for Greater Search Visibility
attachments.text: As bloggers, we often get so drawn into the rush and excitement of creating new content that we forget how valuable our old blog posts are. Tremendous time and effort goes into creating a blog post and if you are not keeping your old posts alive, you are not leveraging your blog content fully. Up
attachments.title: How to Update and Optimize Your Old Blog Posts for Greater Search Visibility

Hi hi :wave::wave: we’ve newly released a B2C product (Apple only app; early literacy; for parents to teach their kids to read) We’re testing a few channels and managed to get one of our YT videos (a super cute ABC song) into suggested feed and have racked up more than 1,2M views in the last 15 days. We’d love to double down but YT is not where my strength is… any ideas?? I’d be in your debt :pray::pray: hope everyone has a spectacular day :fire:

Hi Athena! YT isn't my speciality either, but I'd love to take a look. Can you share a link to the video?

Also, I saw that your  <https://www.reading.com/?utm_source=teaching.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=crosspromo&utm_content=landingpage|Reading.com landing page> still says "Coming 2021" at the top. May want to update that!

attachments.text: What if teaching your child to read felt like magic?
attachments.title: Reading.com

text:
Content topic ideation! :ship: 

Anyone have success building a decision matrix to prioritize what gets created in a way that satisfies multiple stakeholders and adheres to a coherent strategy.. seems like an intractable problem. I'm trying to figure our the best way to make all the directors happy, while executing an effective strategy

text: Can I get a quick yay or nay to product promotion in whitepapers? Is there a way to do it tactfully or avoid at all costs?

elements.text: Can I get a quick yay or nay to product promotion in whitepapers? Is there a way to do it tactfully or avoid at all costs?

text: You can add it before and after the whitepaper... so the first and last page. I've also added a UTM to measure clicks on it. Works like a charm.

elements.text: You can add it before and after the whitepaper... so the first and last page. I've also added a UTM to measure clicks on it. Works like a charm.

text: Excellent point, Kaysie! And it is all marketing work vs product work. I think at some companies, the copywriters are seated within a more general "creative team" org structure, and are very tightly connected to design whereas the "content" team was more dedicated to longform though leadership. Has anyone seen this at their companies?

text:
hi everyone! pretty broad question here but any thoughts and feedback would be helpful :relaxed: how would you prioritize content strategy and distribution channels when:

• keywords are either low volume or are heavily searched by an audience we don't serve
• there isn't an active online community of our target audience
• interest tends to trickle in through word-of-mouth and customer announcements 
my initial thought is to focus on investing time in a few strong pillar pages, creating an exciting newsletter, and building around customer stories. as context, i'm a pretty new 1-person content team, and content strategy prior to this has been more ad hoc. I'd like to introduce more consistency and spend my time on areas that will see visible results. any thoughts on this?

happy to talk through dm for more detail!

elements.text: hi everyone! pretty broad question here but any thoughts and feedback would be helpful

my initial thought is to focus on investing time in a few strong pillar pages, creating an exciting newsletter, and building around customer stories. as context, i'm a pretty new 1-person content team, and content strategy prior to this has been more ad hoc. I'd like to introduce more consistency and spend my time on areas that will see visible results. any thoughts on this?

happy to talk through dm for more detail!

text: Could you capitalize on the WOM/Customer angle with case studies, customer stories or customer spotlights that both you and your customers then share on their own social profiles?

elements.text: Could you capitalize on the WOM/Customer angle with case studies, customer stories or customer spotlights that both you and your customers then share on their own social profiles?

text: Anyone here have experience writing in the bridal/wedding niche, or, have a connection to someone who does? Looking for some referrals for a client.

elements.text: Anyone here have experience writing in the bridal/wedding niche, or, have a connection to someone who does? Looking for some referrals for a client.

text: Hey Matt, I have done several ghostwritten content for multiple clients in that niche. Feel free to DM if you want to connect me with your client.

elements.text: Hey Matt, I have done several ghostwritten content for multiple clients in that niche. Feel free to DM if you want to connect me with your client.

text: thank you for weighing in<@U02K5SJ26PL>! definitely agree with you there and my team is open to doing that. we publish customer stories regularly, some get a steady stream of traffic while many dip quickly once it's been shared — so I'm thinking that continuously distributing and repurposing those stories would be one of the bigger priorities

text: Hey all! I connected with a brand on Instagram in the coffee niche. They're looking for a designer to help with content assets -- anybody work on that? :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hey all! I connected with a brand on Instagram in the coffee niche. They're looking for a designer to help with content assets -- anybody work on that?

text: <@U01HEQWRG0G> I happen to have a former coworker/good friend who has experience in illustrations for a coffee brand here in Portland, Oregon, and just opened up their freelance availability again. Feel free to share their Instagram: <https://www.instagram.com/p/CHdOyHXh9dJ/> I can vouch for his quality of work, ease to work with, and being an all-around lovely person.
